titleStmt.title: M111 Set 1 of 3, [The Reader: But her own passion, the disgrace, the humiliation...]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 5 fols.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

sourceDesc.msDesc:
New York Public Library Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature m111-1 s
M111, Set 1 of 3 [The Reader: But her own passion, the disgrace, the humiliation...]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 5 fols.
Paginated 29-33.
p. 29 with discarded page paginated 34 on verso.
p. 30 with page from story on verso.
p. 32 with page from Between the Acts paginated 155 on verso.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p:
But Her own passion, the disgrace, the humiliation of her are all [actual?] in dumb shows
family are all hidden under silence itself; or such
flourishes and ornaments that reveal nothing (notning). After
that amount to silence (sielnce). The plain country squires, they (the)
are all teased once they take pen in hand by the demon
of poetry. After (Af e) fl flxmxmxmxmxm floundering out a page
of conceits and fantasies (fanatsies), Mr has indeed recourse
to poetry. After trying to explain My conceit of this
triple love, of affection passion and conjunction (conjnuction)" with a
[wandering?] (w nedrin) wealth (welt th) of imagery he quotes ... "... of lae
late I have light upon Mr Spensers (Soensers) opinion so rightly Spensers (Soensers) opinion so rightly agreeing (agreeig)
with that which nature had taught (taight) me before, as the
same might have been thought to have drawn out of his
discipline." It is the poets still who speak for the
squires who cannot (whocannot) speak for themselves (themslces). Yet behind these
florid (gfloird) decorations, these strained elegancies,
the wolves and foxes of the court (cort) prey and raven.
Bastards are born (borb). There is a crude appetite a greed a passion (passin)
which moves under the flowers and suddenly glares at us.
Bastards are born in the flesh. Reputations are ruined.
Only the people themselves (themlves) pass unseen. They too like the
dramatists remain anonymous.

Yet there is a strange contradiction. If the
wr country gentlement (bgentlemen) and their wives must speak in
hyperbole when they write of (f) love, they write of possessions
in plain English. No generation had more anxiety to preserve [illeg.]
their physical bodies from decay. They eat (Theyeat) prodigously.
They wear clothes that are so heavy they can scarcely move
in them. Inventory (Invenory) after inventory records their furniture (furiture),

are all contributions (contrbutions) to our knowledge
of what looked like, if you see him through
a certain vision (visoon). But there always remains
something further. It is this that lures the
reader and (Abd) it is this quality that
finally eludes us. gives him his perpetual vitality,
he excites (ecites) perpetual (perp tual) curiosity. He does not as so many
writers feed momentary appetites (appettites). The reader (resder) who has a dash
of the writer in him, seeks out certain styles; certain
forms. But Shakespeare (Shakespere) has no such (nosuch) appeal to the reader-writer.
His styles are too innumerable (innumerabel) Perhaps (Perhpas) then he is chiefly
used for more general purposes (piposes)--when the ink has gone dry
upon the pen to revive the sense of language (langauge); or to
testify, when words seem motionless (motiinless), to the enormous
possibilities of speed. One reading always supersedes another
Thus the truest (trueest) account of reading Shakespeare (Shakespere) would be
not to write a book with a beginning middle and end;
but to collect notes, without trying to make them
consistent.

their jewels, their horses and carriages. When they die,
heavy marble tombs are raised over them. The outer life
is as substantial (substa tial) as cloth of gold and pigs capons hogs
can make it. But the mind that lives in the head, the
heart that hxxx speak only on the , through the
mouths of the players.
Txmxmxmxmxmxmx

Yet in no age can there have been a deeper gulf
between the artist and society (socity). dedicates his
sonnets to Not one of all those highly educated (eduvated)
nobles troubles to ask who is this patron? It is not a matter
of interest in court circles. The plays are not discussed.
Lord Southampton (Southmapton) and Lord Rutland, wrote to
, pass away the time in London, merely in
going to plays every (ev y) day" But the attraction of the stage
called forth no comment. The players lived too far from the
court to stir curiosity. They were too much of servants,
too much of minstrels, jugglers bear (nbear) leaders (laeders) to
be a proper topic for gossip. Thus the early works of
Shakespeare (Shakeepare) make no ripple in the pool of silence (sielnce).
No one protests that here is an upstart writer who is
for throwing (throwin) society into the melting pot. The great (grreat) might
be mocked--that was the ancient (anicient) privilege of the court
jester (jster); or some scene from history reenacted (re encated). But the
was quick to control irreverence. And in fact the dramatist
wasn ot destroying society. The indignation that, after the
first silent surprise, that for example stirred in
London was partly the rage of those who felt that
stop in the middle of her song. and shut the piano.

Her father beat her oftener and oftener (oftner).
She would show the marks on her flesh in the kitchen.
"The squire didnt out to" said Pink the groom.
xmxmxmxmxm Jinny the parlourmaid agreed would have agreed.; but her cough
prevented her xxxx
Stxxx

There were many legs on the alwn lawn in the summer.
She would watch them from between the raspberry (rasperry) canes,
where she had a cave A grass path led between the bushes,
and once the legs came walking there; and her brother(
in (ni) white flannel) stooped; and the girl in a white skirt (shkirt)
who was with him stooped (stopped) too.

Hullo Elizabeth (LElizabeth)" said her brother. " Cut (VCut) along (alkng)
into the house and (houseand) fetch my pipe; and I'll give you sixpence (sipence)"
She guessed it was not his pipe he wanted; but to be
rid of her. So she mooned round the library looking at the
great pictures.

They had been in that house for ever so long.
And the great pictures were almost part of the walls.
They were ancestors; children; youths; grown men and women;
sea captains; bishops. And the strange men used to look at
them and make (andmake) notes in their pocket books.

The only person she saw whole, from her yellow head
to her little black slippers, was Carry Elmer, the daughter (duag ter)
of another squire.

At intervals of ten miles apart there (ther) were then
great houses. Perry Hall, the Elmers (E;mers) house, was famous.

The Elizabethan audience were not readers. They had to
draw in the play as they sat or stood at the playhouse,
through their ears, through their eyes. There was no book
of the (thee) words. They could not dxxxx deepen the impression,
chew it over, and compare it, at a table (atble) in a private room.
This perhaps explains (exp;ains) the scarcity of Elizabethan
criticism; and the general nature of what [certain?] there is.
Both (Bioth) and deal with the general (neral)
not with the particular (particualr); with the rules of composition (compsition),
not with the (t e) details of one play or poem in particular (partciualr).
It accounts too for the long pause between [sixteenth? seventeenth?] & the 18th centuries when the plays of
even hang suspended and unrealised. It was only
when they had to [wait?] they were printed and the book of the words lay in many
private rooms txxxx before they received their other life from
the reader. Much that was lost in the playhouse (playhous e) was
discovered in the private room. But much has also been lost , when the
We have lost the sound of the spoken word; all that the
sight of the actors body gives through the eye to the mind.
We have lost too the sense of being part of the audience.
We miss a thousand shades that the dramatist conveyed (darmatistconveyed)by inflection of voice, by gesture, by the placing (palcing) of
the actors bodies (vbodies). This can still be tested, at least with
Shakespeare, by comparing (comapring) whxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxx our impression
xmxmxmxmxmxxx after seeing the play (p ay) with our
impression after reading the play. But as the modern actor
inevitably imports much that is of his own day, but foreign
to Shakespeare (Shshakespeare), there is still something sunk beyond
beyond recall.

Presumably the earlier plays, in which the (whichnthe) (pplaywright)
was more at the (tge) mercy of the audience, are the more damaged
by reading (rreading) them xmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxx The reader instinctively
tries to be there in person. He tries to supply (sup ly) the trumpets (trumepts)
and the flags; the citizens and the apprentices.
He furbishes himself nourishes himself with a dip into ,
with a dip into . He makes an effort to supply (sppply) what
is so obviously the sunk part of the play. But he is perpetually (perp)
perpetually (tually) rebuffed. He is apt pat to become not a reader but a
student; txmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmmxmxmx a collector of
scattered bones. At some point however in the Elizabethan
drama the reader (rezder) is born. There are speeches (spepeches) and scenes (scnes)
that call upon his special faculty. When the dramatist
becomes conscious of the play as a work of art; when he
becomes able to unite the play by a unity which is
not that of the plot-- by something in himself his [illeg.], his [illeg.]
by some individuality of his style, of his whole temper,
It is the apprehension of this power at work
it is this apprehension that serves to draw (drow) together the
faculties which are proper to the reader.
that (th t) brings the reader into being.

The reader has been in existence for round
about four hundred (hubdred) years. But his life history (hisotry) is an
obscure one. At some point his ear must have lost its acuteness (a uten)
acuteness; then his eyes became dull. Then he became word
conscious, aware of suggestions and echoes. As time passed (paassed),
he imported into the written (writteh) word much that was
unintended by the writer. A word spelt in the Elizabethan

homes (ho mes) will be built. Each flat with With refrigerators in each flat?
xmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxm xxxx And churches...
The tune changed. It chopped and changed. It broke off. It
broke up. With the (Withthe) means at her (he) disposal (dispoal) you couldnt ask too
much (mcu). Thxmxmxmxmxmxmx; What a cackle; a cacophony (cocophony)...
like the yaffle, a they call the woodpecker. The laughing
bird who flits from tree to tree. Out they skipped.
Children? Imps --elfs... Out they skipped. The riff raff
of the village... Holding what? Tin cans? Bed room candle
sticks? Shaving glasses? Old tabacco (tobbaco) jars? My dear, thats the
cheval (cehval) glass from the rectory... and the mirror-- I lent her.
My mother's (motgers)... And grandpa's (grabdpas) old top hat! Whats the notion?
Anything thats bright enough, presumably, to reflect (refelct)...
Thats the mens shaving glass from the stable..
Mrs Sands, did you really lend her that?
Ourselves Ourselves?

the meaning of words is tremendously developed; so that they
remain attached to certain aspects of the printed page;
the scholars (sch ars) the students whxmxmxmxmxmxx, Again there is
the very large class of perfectly literate (literatue) people (peole) who run (whorun)
their eyes over miles of print yearly, yet never read a w
word. Txmxmxmxxx The reader, distinct from the scholar (schoar),
distinct from the print stripper of news paper print,
has a curious power (p wer) to make houses and countries
visible, men and women (womn) and their thoughts and emotion,
from marks on a piece of paper. His faculty is always changing (changig)
The reader again (agains) is always changing. The is now
developing (develpojg) his eyes, the is developing (dev pojg) his ear.
He is still in existence; for it is a fact that
he is still causing (casuing) books to be printed.
He is still reading Shakespeare (Sjakespere).
